POR.DRECONTENT:
The project in addition to teaching supported the PI's postdoc at Stanford University. This gave the PI an opportunity to continue his research in mathematics and theoretical computer science. During this time, the PI forged a number of new collaborations and layed the groundwork for over a dozen papers on a number of different topics. The areas studied by the PI during this time period include the following:

* Number theory: and in particular work on the study of elliptic curves and in particular on the statistics of sizes of Selmer groups of curves in various families.

* Combinatorics: including work on the distribution of statistics of random set partitions and on a counting problem related to integer partitions.

* Complexity theory: with a focus on problems relating to the study of Boolean functions and in particular to polynomial threshold functions. This work included a number of new, more efficient pseudorandom generators for polynomial threshold functions, substantial improvements on the known bounds on the noise sensitivity of polynomial threshold functions, and new and powerful structural results for analyzing low degree polynomials in many variables. This work has substantially improved our understanding of these fundamental objects of study and may well find applications to a number of problems in complexity theory.


Last Modified: 10/30/2015
Modified by: Daniel M Kane

This gave the PI an opportunity to continue his research in mathematics and theoretical computer science. The areas studied by the PI during this time period include the following: * Number theory: and in particular work on the study of elliptic curves and in particular on the statistics of sizes of Selmer groups of curves in various families. * Combinatorics: including work on the distribution of statistics of random set partitions and on a counting problem related to integer partitions. * Complexity theory: with a focus on problems relating to the study of Boolean functions and in particular to polynomial threshold functions. This work included a number of new, more efficient pseudorandom generators for polynomial threshold functions, substantial improvements on the known bounds on the noise sensitivity of polynomial threshold functions, and new and powerful structural results for analyzing low degree polynomials in many variables. This work has substantially improved our understanding of these fundamental objects of study and may well find applications to a number of problems in complexity theory.
